docs.lead_paragraph: One important issue of the health care debate is what to do with the employer-based health insurance system. As Uwe Reinhardt has written, nowhere else in the industrialized world does losing your job also mean losing your health care.
docs.abstract: Many American companies do not offer health insurance to their employees.
docs.snippet: Many American companies do not offer health insurance to their employees.

docs.lead_paragraph: Leading Democrats seem open to nearly any idea so long as it will lead to passing legislation, perhaps at the expense of passing sensible legislation.
docs.snippet: Leading Democrats seem open to nearly any idea so long as it will lead to passing legislation, perhaps at the expense of passing sensible legislation.

docs.lead_paragraph: The White House is trying to shift the health care debate away from Washington and to the states.

headline.seo: To Pressure Congress, Obama Seek Popular Support for Health Care Reform
headline.main: Obama Steers Health Debate Out of Capital
headline.print_headline: Obama Steers Health Debate Out of Capital

docs.snippet: The White House is trying to shift the health care debate away from Washington and to the states.

docs.lead_paragraph: At the end of their shifts tomorrow, the three newest police officers in the Maplewood Police Department will be out of jobs. The deadline for the layoffs is tomorrow, and, according to Maplewood Mayor Victor DeLuca, no new deal is in sight.
docs.abstract: Tomorrow will likely be the last day for three police officers in Maplewood, after the police department rejected a contract with concessions that could have avoided the job losses.
docs.snippet: Tomorrow will likely be the last day for three police officers in Maplewood, after the police department rejected a contract with concessions that could have avoided the job losses.

docs.lead_paragraph: First lady Michelle Obama visited a local health clinic in Washington on Tuesday in an effort to focus attention on preventable scourges such as obesity, diabetes and high blood pressure that disproportionately afflict African-American and Hispanic communities.

headline.main: First Lady Tours a Health Clinic

docs.abstract: Michelle Obama visits a local center that caters to the uninsured and the homeless.
docs.snippet: Michelle Obama visits a local center that caters to the uninsured and the homeless.

docs.lead_paragraph: Two influential Democrats with close ties to President Obama endorsed on Monday taxing some employer-provided health benefits as part of a $1.2 trillion 10-year framework for financing a health system overhaul, another sign that Mr. Obama may end up accepting a tax that he rejected during his campaign.

headline.main: Daschle and Podesta: Taxing Employer Plans Should Be Considered

docs.abstract: Two influential Democrats with close ties to President Obama have endorsed taxing some employer-provided health benefits as part of a $1.2 trillion 10-year framework for financing a health system overhaul.
docs.snippet: Two influential Democrats with close ties to President Obama have endorsed taxing some employer-provided health benefits as part of a $1.2 trillion 10-year framework for financing a health system overhaul.

docs.lead_paragraph: Maybe consumers - especially the ones reading this blog - aren't so irrational after all. In my Findings column, I describe how the patrons of a restaurant in Israel turned out to be surprisingly immune to the experimental manipulations of behavioral economists. And now there's more evidence of sensible shopping behavior from an informal (and unscientific) survey of Lab readers. It was conducted in connection with an earlier column about Geoffrey Miller's new book, "Spent: Sex, Evolution and Consumer Behavior." Dr. Miller issued an open invitation to readers to try this exercise:
docs.abstract: Maybe consumers - especially diners in Israel and the readers of this blog -- aren't so irrational after all. There's evidence of sensible shopping behavior from an informal survey conducted among Lab readers.
docs.snippet: Maybe consumers - especially diners in Israel and the readers of this blog -- aren't so irrational after all. There's evidence of sensible shopping behavior from an informal survey conducted among Lab readers.

docs.lead_paragraph: Update | 12:45 p.m. Sentenced to 150 years in prison on Monday, Bernard L. Madoff, the convicted Ponzi schemer, got one of the nation's most severe sentences ever handed out in a white-collar crime case.

headline.main: White-Collar Jail Terms: Who Got What

docs.abstract: As Bernard L. Madoff, the confessed Ponzi schemer, prepares to learn his sentence today, DealBook takes a graphical look at of some of the longest prison terms for financial fraud.
docs.snippet: As Bernard L. Madoff, the confessed Ponzi schemer, prepares to learn his sentence today, DealBook takes a graphical look at of some of the longest prison terms for financial fraud.

docs.lead_paragraph: As health care reform moves forward, Congress must impose tighter regulation of companies that are not doing enough to regulate themselves.
docs.snippet: As health care reform moves forward, Congress must impose tighter regulation of companies that are not doing enough to regulate themselves.

docs.lead_paragraph: Republicans called the plan passed by the House a national energy tax that would drive manufacturers and jobs to countries with less-strict emissions standards.

headline.main: Republicans Highly Critical of House Energy Bill
headline.print_headline: Republicans Highly Critical of House Energy Bill

docs.snippet: Republicans called the plan passed by the House a national energy tax that would drive manufacturers and jobs to countries with less-strict emissions standards.
